item.title: Massimo Pigliucci on death and Stoicism - Aeon Videos
item.description:
Massimo Pigliucci on death and Stoicism - Aeon Videos

For the Stoic, death is an open door, and the freedom to walk through it enables us to live a virtuous life

item.title: A Century Ago, Einstein's Theory of Relativity Changed Everything
item.description:
A Century Ago, Einstein's Theory of Relativity Changed Everything

PRINCETON, N.J. - By the fall of 1915, Albert Einstein was a bit grumpy. And why not? Cheered on, to his disgust, by most of his Berlin colleagues, Germany had started a ruinous world war. He had split up with his wife, and she had decamped to Switzerland with his sons.

item.title: The Strange Story of the Disappearing Volcano Island
item.description:
The Strange Story of the Disappearing Volcano Island

0

item.title: Adele: Inside Her Private Life and Triumphant Return
item.description:
Adele: Inside Her Private Life and Triumphant Return

As Adele steers through a South London high street in her four-door Mini Cooper, with her toddler's vacant car seat in back and the remains of a kale, cucumber and almond-milk concoction in the cup holder, a question occurs to her. "What's been going on in the world of music?"

item.title: 'The Good Is Elusive and Transitory in This World'
item.description:
'The Good Is Elusive and Transitory in This World'

Few things remind me of how much beauty there is in the world as clearly and reliably as Maira Kalman's work. An author, artist and designer, Kalman has written and illustrated dozens of books for children and adults, including The Principles of Uncertainty I visited Kalman at her incredible apartment in New York City, itself a kind of mini-museum.

item.title: Susan Cain on Teaching Introverted Children
item.description:
Susan Cain on Teaching Introverted Children

Do you remember the news story about Natalie Munro, the high school English teacher from Pennsylvania who blogged her true feelings about her students? Apparently failing to comprehend the public nature of the Internet, she mused about the nasty things she wished she could write on her students' report cards.

item.title: U.S. Public Becoming Less Religious
item.description:
U.S. Public Becoming Less Religious

Modest Drop in Overall Rates of Belief and Practice, but Religiously Affiliated Americans Are as Observant as Before Is the American public becoming less religious? Yes, at least by some key measures of what it means to be a religious person. An extensive new survey of more than 35,000 U.S.

item.title: Voted the Worst King in History, It's No Surprise He Doesn't Get Credit for His Greatest Achievement
item.description:
Voted the Worst King in History, It's No Surprise He Doesn't Get Credit for His Greatest Achievement

"What's that smell?" I asked my dad as we approached Rievaulx Abbey on a visit to Yorkshire, England. "It's wild garlic," he said - which I'd later learn was a surprising crop to find so far north, though the story behind the monastery would prove even more surprising.
